t: For the choir director, for Jeduthun. A Psalm of David.
I*pn said, “I will guard my ways That*ln I may not sin with my tongue; I*ln will guard my mouth as with a muzzle While*ln the wicked are in my presence.”
I*ln was mute and silent, I*ln refrained even*i from good, And*ln my sorrow grew worse.
My*ln heart was hot within me, While*ln I was musing the fire burned; Then*iln I spoke with my tongue:
“Lord,*sln make me to know my end And*ln what is the extent of my days; Let*ln me know how transient I am.
Behold,*ln You have made my days as*i handbreadths, And*ln my lifetime as nothing in Your sight; Surely*ln every man at his best is a mere breath. Selah.
Surely*ln every man walks about as a phantom; Surely*ln they make an uproar for nothing; He*ln amasses riches*i and does not know who will gather them.
“And*ln now, Lord, for what do I wait? My*ln hope is in You.
Deliver*ln me from all my transgressions; Make*ln me not the reproach of the foolish.
I*ln have become mute, I do not open my mouth, Because*ln it is You who have done it.*i
Remove*ln Your plague from me; Because*ln of the opposition of Your hand I am perishing.
With*ln reproofs You chasten a man for iniquity; You*ln consume as a moth what is precious to him; Surely*ln every man is a mere breath. Selah.
“Hear*ln my prayer, O Lord,*s and give ear to my cry; Do*ln not be silent at my tears; For*ln I am a stranger with You, A*ln sojourner like all my fathers.
Turn*ln Your gaze away from me, that I may smile again*i Before*ln I depart and am no more.”
